awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Baseline for Antarctic Blue and Fin Whales
awd_abstract_narration:
Blue and fin whales are the two largest animals on the planet, and the two largest krill predators in the Southern Ocean. Commercial whaling in Antarctic waters started in the early 1900?s, and by the 1970's whale populations were reduced from thousands to only a few hundred individuals. The absence of data about whale biology and ecology prior to these large population reductions has limited our understanding of how the ecosystem functioned when cetacean populations were more robust. However, an archive of baleen plates from 800 Antarctic blue and fin whales harvested between 1946 and 1948 was recently rediscovered in the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History that will shed insight into historic whale ecology. As baleen grows, it incorporates circulating hormones, and compounds from the whale's diet, recording continuous biological and oceanographic information across multiple years. This project will apply a suite of modern molecular techniques to these archived specimens to ask how blue and fin whale foraging and reproduction responded to climate variability, changes at the base of the food web, and whaling activities in the early 1940s. By comparison with more modern datasets, these investigations will fill major gaps in understanding of the largest krill predators, their response to disturbance and environmental change, and the impact that commercial whaling has had on the structure and function of the Antarctic marine ecosystem. This project will improve stem education through annual programming for middle and high school girls in partnership with UNCW's Marine Quest program. Public outreach will occur through partnerships with the Smithsonian and the International Association of Antarctic Tour Operators to deliver emerging research on Antarctic ecosystems and highlight the contemporary relevance and scientific value of museum collections. 

Examination of past conditions and adaptations of polar biota is fundamental to predictions of future climate change scenarios. The baleen record that will be used in this study forms an ideal experimental platform for studying bottom-up, top-down and anthropogenic impacts on blue and fin whales. This historic baleen archive includes years with strong climate and temperature anomalies allowing the influence of climate variability on predators and the ecosystems that support them to be examined. Additionally, the impact of commercial whaling on whale stress levels will be investigated by comparing years of intensive whaling with the non-whaling years of WWII, both of which are captured in the time series. There are three main approaches to this project. First, bulk stable isotope analysis will be used to examine the trophic dynamics of Antarctic blue and fin whales. Second, compound-specific stable isotope analyses (CSIA-AA) will characterize the biogeochemistry of the base of the Antarctic food web. Finally, analyses of hormone levels in baleen will reveal differences in stress levels and reproductive status of individuals, and inform understanding of cetacean population biology. This project will generate a new public data archive to foster research opportunities across various components of the OPP program, all free from the logistical constraints of Antarctic field work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on Antarctic blue and fin whales, both nearly hunted to extinction from commercial whaling, and now estimated to number just 1-4% of their pre-whaling abundance. Their rarity makes them an urgent target for scientific research yet exceptionally challenging to study. However, a long-forgotten treasure trove in the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History was recently uncovered and provided an unparalleled chance to investigate these exceptional species. Over 1500 plates of baleen, each about a meter long, were sent to the museum from Japanese whaling expeditions immediately following World War II during the period of US occupation. A recent international effort linked the provenance and history of these plates, providing critical metadata on each piece of baleen, paving the way for the research we conducted under this grant. By combining these historical archives with modern molecular methods including stable isotope analyses and hormone analyses, we gained new understanding of these species’ migrations, foraging, reproduction, and response to anthropogenic activities.

 

These were the first baleen plates to be analyzed from Antarctic blue and fin whales and they revealed approximately 6 years of life history data in blue whales and 4 years in fin whales. As a result, these plates provided a longitudinal view of their foraging and migration across multiple years of their life at approximately monthly time scales from ~1940-1947, pre-dating modern satellite records of the Antarctic ecosystem and more rapid declines in climate-change induced ice loss. Second, these samples revealed information about ecological niche separation between these two similar species. Blue and fin whales are the two largest predators in the Southern Ocean, with similarities in morphology and distribution. They are both known to feed on krill and long-standing questions have surrounded their ecological niche differentiation, especially when their populations were still in high abundance. How did they avoid competition? These high-resolution data sets revealed that the two predators feed at the same trophic level and likely the same prey type but demonstrate niche differentiation, likely through spatial separation with blue whales remaining closer to the ice edge. Third, the specimens showed differences in migratory behavior. Fin whales appeared to have regular annual migrations while blue whales showed less predictable annual movements. Fourth, and quite surprisingly, isotopic signatures in most of the blue whales sampled suggested that the blue whales remained in the Southern Ocean year-round, not migrating seasonally to sub-Antarctic and temperate waters as all other large whale species are thought to do. Further analyses using compound-specific stable isotopes are underway and more results regarding species movements, foraging, and physiology are forthcoming.

 

In addition to isotope signatures, hormone analyses provided insights on these species’ endocrinology, reproduction, and responses to anthropogenic activities. Results to date include finding regular testosterone cycles in male specimens, confirming a seasonality to reproductive activity. One of the most alarming findings from this project is the finding that whales stress-hormone levels changed throughout the timeseries contained within the baleen plates. In particular, stress levels showed peaks in 1946, the same year that whaling resumed in the Southern Ocean after pausing operations during World War II. After ruling out other potential environmental and reproductive explanations, the data support a “whaling effect” – that the resumption of whaling activities registered marked increases in average stress levels, recorded permanently in the baleen plates of the two largest predators in the world’s oceans. More work is ongoing with the specimens sampled to date but already this collection has revealed a plethora of insights into the lives, resilience, and vulnerability of these two remarkable species and the Antarctic ecosystem.   

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Alyson H Fleming
